results.title: Shipbuilding in Australia
results.brief_description: A brief history of the shipbuilding industry in Australia, and a record of the designing, building, launching and trials of an Australian ship. Includes the initial planning by the designer; the steel stockyard, building berth and fitting berth; and the slip-way where the ship is constructed and launched, and after which all the fittings such as radar, wireless, and rigging are installed. Also sea trials and handing over.

results.title: Shipbuilding I
results.brief_description: “Summary: set in port glasgow, this film describes how a systems approach can be used in the analysis of a shipyard system. a series of questions are posed and the way in which one might begin to explore them is indicated. the often encountered difficulty of reconciling opposing viewpoints in the systems approach (eg. divergence of management/worker opinions) is also highlighted. narrated by John Naughton”

results.title: Shipbuilding 2
results.brief_description: SUMMARY: The 1971 work-in at Upper Clyde shipbuilders is used as a means of demonstrating the interaction of components of a system under extreme conditions

results.title: Shepherd dog and his flock
results.brief_description: Shows the day’s activities of two German Shepherd dogs and the shepherd for whom they work. Reveals how both dogs handle the flock of sheep and keep it moving toward pasture. No narration.

results.title: Sheltered workshops
results.creator_credit: Kit Guyatt, David Bairstow and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Shows how sheltered workshops provide training and employment for variously handicapped people. Discusses the main problems in organising a local centre. Explains the work being done to encourage and assist disabled and handicapped people. About 150,000 Australians of working age are so seriously handicapped, mentally or physically, that they are unable to join the normal workforce. Today more than 5,000 are usefully and gainfully employed in a growing community movement - the sheltered workshop.

results.title: Shell fishing
results.brief_description: Along the eastern coast of the united States, fishermen gather from the ocean and bays many different types of shellfish - oysters, crabs, clams, lobsters - using lines, traps and nets. Their catches are shipped fresh to many parts of the USA, with the aid of special packing and refrigeration; canned, they are exported all over the world. This film uses dialog recorded among the fishermen in various parts of the east coast of USA, thus emphasizing the rgionals differences in speech

results.title: Sheffield made
results.creator_credit: John S. Green, Frank Green and Ace Films
results.brief_description: How the steelmakers of Sheffield, with their traditions of skill and craftsmanship, are producing special steels. Shows how these same traditions, backed by research and modern equipment, are meeting the demands of designers and engineers, in the aviation industry and the construction of atomic power stations.

results.title: Sheet steel for a nation
results.brief_description: Describes the process of cold reduction of sheet steel as a stage in the production of galvanised, corrugated and other types of steel sheets. This process was first intoroduced in 1955 at Port Kembla in New South Wales. Shows how in the major operation, the steel strip rolls through rollers which exert tremendous pressure in reducing the steel to the required thickness.

results.title: Sheet metal in industry
results.creator_credit: Bruce McNaughton and Academy Film Productions
results.brief_description: Sheet metal work in Australia, showing manufacture of varied articles including domestic hardware, surgical instruments, refrigerator cabinets, heating and ventilating ducts, vehicle bodies and jet engines. Shows the kinds of work available in the field
